awd_titl_txt: CAREER: On the Neural and Mechanistic Bases of Higher-order Cognition
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to explore the neural basis of how higher-order cognitive processes facilitate a representation of our environment. To date, the vast majority of decision-making research uses relatively simple stimuli to systematically relate independent variables within an experiment to collected dependent variables such as response time, EEG, or fMRI measures. However, the decisions that we make in our everyday lives are significantly more complicated. We exist in environments where resource and reward structures change dynamically on a daily, even momentary, basis. In these environments, cognitive control is necessary to successfully adjust our goals and representations to match the dynamics of our environment. Data from the experiments conducted during this project, as well the analytic methods, will be used to create a comprehensive syllabus in the emerging field of model-based cognitive neuroscience.  The materials, data, and code for performing the analyses will also be made available to the broader scientific community, so that other universities may adopt the course sequence.


Cognitive control is essential to successfully adjust our goals and representations to match dynamic changes in the environment. It is argued that our understanding of the mechanisms by which control is carried out in the brain is limited by the lack of statistical methodology to (1) rigorously investigate cognitive models equipped with mechanisms of control, (2) relate mechanisms of control to brain data, and (3) justify the inclusion of complicated mechanisms by assessing model fit and complexity. In this proposal, I hope to use hierarchical (Bayesian) joint modeling techniques to address each of these three limitations. The hierarchical component of this research is specifically designed to assess individual variation in the degree to which cognitive control is executed. The joint modeling component of this research is designed to link neurophysiological measures (e.g., EEG, fMRI) to cognitive theories about how control is executed. Finally, to fully examine the degree to which stochastic mechanisms of control may best describe individual subject data, I will build on existing techniques I have developed for approximating these processes through likelihood-free Bayesian methodology. Each of these components will be used collectively to systematically examine the neural basis of control in various cognitive tasks, and specifically the degree to which individuals are capable of successfully executing said control.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project was designed to explore the computational and neural bases of higher order cognition, such as decision making and learning. In the beginning of the project, my team developed statistical methods for linking activity that occured in the brain to theories of cognition, so that these theories could be properly tested against actual brain data. In so doing, we created a platform for enhancing the evaluation and validation of current theories on cognition. Once we developed this platform, we were able to build experimental infrastructures that allowed us to run experiments that would automatically tune itself to the participant in the experiment, presenting stimuli that would maximize the amount of information a research could learn about the particular way in which a person used their brain to make the decisions that they did on each trial. During the project period, progress was hindered by the COVID epidemic, making it temporarily difficult to collect subject data (especially for fMRI and EEG experiments). As such, my team shifted to developing new theories that explain how selecdtive attention shapes the learning process. We validated this new theory by using open source data which resulted in several publications in top tier theoretical journals. Following the pandemic, we returned to data collection that targeted specific questions about how learning occurs across the human life span (by comparing children, younger adults, and older adults), how learning occurs across different species of animals (by comparing learning in rats, pigeons, and humans), and understanding how algorithms used to curate knowledge (such as Google, YouTube, etc) might interact with human partipants and whether this interaction could potentially hinder optimal learning if the goal of the learner were misaligned with the goal of the curation algorithm. We also investigated whether the model we developed had any connection to what occured in the human brain during learning. Our results suggested that the model's 'learning signal' closely resembled the brain activity expressed in human partcipants during a category learning experiment. Finally, we recently used the model to explain why patients with tramatic brain injuries had such specific learning failures given the focus and extent of the damaged areas. 

 

The research here supported the careers of two (female) postdoctoral students and an (female) graduate student, allowing them to learn how to do quality compuational cognitive science, disseminate the results, and plan new experiments and theoretical models. The reseach in his project closely connected the fields of cognitive science, cognitive neuroscience, and challeneged existing frameworks for learning commonly used in machine learning and computational neuroscience. We hope that the multifaceted success of the learning models we developed in this project help motivate a deeper understanding of what it means to learn as a human.
